bibdata.title: Implementers' guide for Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354

abstract.p: This document is an Implementers' Guide for Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354 (2016-04).
This version contains all updates submitted up to and including those at Study Group 15 meeting in January/February 2020.
This document was approved by ITU-T Study Group 15 on 7 February 2020

series.title: G: Transmission Systems and Media, Digital Systems and Networks

localized-strings.localized-string: This Recommendation defines the following terms:
This Recommendation defines the following terms:

The following ITU-T Recommendations and other references contain provisions which, through reference in this text, constitute provisions of this Recommendation. At the time of publication, the editions indicated were valid. All Recommendations and other references are subject to revision; users of this Recommendation are therefore encouraged to investigate the possibility of applying the most recent edition of the Recommendations and other references listed below. A list of the currently valid ITU-T Recommendations is regularly published. The reference to a document within this Recommendation does not give it, as a stand-alone document, the status of a Recommendation.
This Recommendation uses the following terms defined elsewhere:

localized-string.p: For the purposes of this document, the terms and definitions given in % and the following apply.

(This annex forms an integral part of this %.)

semantic__bibdata.semantic__title: Implementers' guide for Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354

semantic__abstract.semantic__p: This document is an Implementers' Guide for Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354 (2016-04).
This version contains all updates submitted up to and including those at Study Group 15 meeting in January/February 2020.
This document was approved by ITU-T Study Group 15 on 7 February 2020

semantic__series.semantic__title: G: Transmission Systems and Media, Digital Systems and Networks

semantic__clause.semantic__p: All rights reserved. No part of this publication may be reproduced, by any means whatsoever, without the prior written permission of ITU.

The International Telecommunication Union (ITU) is the United Nations specialized agency in the field of telecommunications , information and communication technologies (ICTs). The ITU Telecommunication Standardization Sector (ITU-T) is a permanent organ of ITU. ITU-T is responsible for studying technical, operating and tariff questions and issuing Recommendations on them with a view to standardizing telecommunications on a worldwide basis.

The World Telecommunication Standardization Assembly (WTSA), which meets every four years, establishes the topics for study by the ITU T study groups which, in turn, produce Recommendations on these topics.
The approval of ITU-T Recommendations is covered by the procedure laid down in WTSA Resolution 1.
In some areas of information technology which fall within ITU-T's purview, the necessary standards are prepared on a collaborative basis with ISO and IEC.

semantic__abstract.semantic__p: This document is an Implementers' Guide for Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354 (2016-04).
This version contains all updates submitted up to and including those at Study Group 15 meeting in January/February 2020.
This document was approved by ITU-T Study Group 15 on 7 February 2020

semantic__clause.semantic__p: This guide provides a list of the definitions that were deleted from Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354 when moved to their source Recommendations.
This implementers' guide is a compilation of reported defects for all versions of Recommendation ITU-T G.8001. In this edition of the guide, reported defects identified as of 2018-10 are given for:
Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354 (2016-04)

The guide must be read in conjunction with Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354 (2016-04) to serve as an additional source of information for implementers. The changes, clarifications and corrections defined herein are expected to be included in future versions of the affected Recommendations.

Upon discovering technical defects with any components of the texts covered by this implementers' guide, please provide a written description directly to the editors of the affected Recommendation(s) with a copy to the respective Rapporteur (See contacts above). The template for a defect report is located at the end of this guide. Return contact information should also be supplied so a dialogue can be established to resolve the matter and an appropriate reply to the defect report can be conveyed. This defect resolution process is open to any interested party. Formal membership in the ITU is not required to participate in this process.
In addition to traditional revision marks, the following marks and symbols are used to indicate to the reader how changes to the text of a Recommendation should be applied:

semantic__tr.semantic__td: Identifies the start of revision marked text based on extractions from the published Recommendations affected by the correction being described.
Identifies the end of revision marked text based on extractions from the published Recommendations affected by the correction being described.
Indicates that the portion of the Recommendation between the text appearing before and after this symbol has remained unaffected by the correction being described and has been omitted for brevity.
Indicates a set of special editing instructions to be followed.

semantic__clause.semantic__title: Technical and editorial corrections to Recommendation ITU-T G.8001

semantic__clause.semantic__p: This Recommendation defines the following terms:

An Ethernet connection of which the traffic units are encapsulated with a backbone VLAN tag (B-Tag) when they are transported through an Ethernet link. Outside an Ethernet link, the traffic units are without a backbone VLAN tag; the information transported in the backbone VLAN tag is presented as a set of parameters: priority, drop eligible and EC identifier. The link end performs the mapping of those parameters into the backbone VLAN tag and the demapping of these parameters from the backbone VLAN tag.Backbone Ethernet connection is referred to in .

An Ethernet connection of which the traffic units are encapsulated with the first 48 bits of a backbone service instance tag (I-Tag) when they are transported through an Ethernet link. Outside an Ethernet link, the traffic units are without a backbone service instance tag; the information transported in the backbone service instance tag is presented as a set of parameters: priority, drop eligible and EC identifier. The link end performs the mapping of those parameters into the backbone service instance tag and the demapping of these parameters from the backbone service instance tag.Backbone service Ethernet connection is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: The entity that has ownership authority over a set of flow points. The customer may have one or more service instances.
Customer is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: An Ethernet connection (EC) of which the traffic units are encapsulated with a customer VLAN tag (C-Tag) when they are transported through an Ethernet link. Outside an Ethernet link, the traffic units are without a customer VLAN tag; the information transported in the customer VLAN tag is presented as a set of parameters: priority, drop eligible and EC identifier. The link end performs the mapping of those parameters into the customer VLAN tag and the demapping of these parameters from the customer VLAN tag.Customer Ethernet connection is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: A type of protocol messaging whereby an initiating MEP sends a request PDU to a receiving peer MEP, which does not send any response. In performance monitoring, the receiving MEP performs measurement calculations.
Dual-ended is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: An NNI for the transfer of ETH_CI traffic units over a transport layer network.EoT-NNI is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: An entity that is responsible for the protection of a subset of the VLANs that transport traffic over the physical Ethernet ring. Each ERP instance is independent of other ERP instances that may be configured on the physical Ethernet ring.
ERP instance is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: A function providing a management communication channel between a pair of maintenance entity group (MEG) end points (MEP). The MCC can be used to perform remote management. The specific use of MCC is outside the scope of this Recommendation. An MEP can send a frame with ETH-MCC information to its peer MEP with a remote maintenance request, remote maintenance reply, notification, etc. Configuration information needs to be provisioned to the MEP to support MCC functions. See for detailed information and the protocol data unit (PDU) structure of the MCC.ET.MCC is defined in as EoT MCC.
A group of ETH_CI signals that is monitored as a single MEG. For this purpose, ETH OAM is added to one of the ETH_CI signals in the group.ETH_CI group is referred to in .

The following set of signals defined in : ETH_CI Data (D), ETH_CI priority (P), ETH_CI drop eligibility (DE), ETH_CI server signal fail (SSF) and optionally ETH_CI automatic protection switching (APS). The ETH_CI_D signal carries the traffic unit that consists of the following fields: destination address (DA), source address (SA) and MAC service data unit (M_SDU).ETH_CI traffic unit is defined in clause 6.3.1 of and referred to in .

Connection point between <Srv>/ETH adaptation source and sink. ETH_CI from source Ethernet flow point (ETH_FP) is replicated and delivered across ETHF_PP to sink Ethernet termination flow point (ETH_TFP).ETHF_PP is referred to in .
Replicated ETH_CI delivered across ETHTF_PP or ETHF_PP.ETH_PI is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: A collection of Ethernet ring nodes forming a closed physical loop whereby each Ethernet ring node is connected to two adjacent Ethernet ring nodes via a duplex communications facility.
Ethernet ring is referred to in .
A network element that implements at least the following functionality.
One Ethernet connection function (ETH_C) with a dedicated Ethernet flow forwarding function (ETH_FF) for forwarding ring automatic protection switching (R-APS) control traffic.
Two ring ports, including ETHDi/ETH adaptation function at the ring maintenance entity group level (MEL).
Ethernet ring protection (ERP) control process controlling the blocking and unblocking of traffic over the ring ports.
Ethernet ring node is referred to in .

An Ethernet service supports an Ethernet flow (as specified in ). It is determined by the topology of the Ethernet network and a corresponding set of attributes associated with the Ethernet connection (EC), the UNI ports and NNI ports.
Ethernet service is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: Connection point between <Srv>/ETH adaptation source and sink. ETH_CI from source Ethernet termination flow point (ETH_TFP) is replicated and delivered across ETHTF_PP to sink filter process.ETHTF_PP is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: EVC is defined in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The highest ETH MEG level in a set of eight MEG levels.ETH path is referred to in .
The lowest ETH MEG level in a set of eight MEG levels.ETH section is referred to in .
An intermediate ETH MEG level in a set of eight MEG levels.ETH tandem connection is referred to in .

A subset of a TMN that is responsible for managing those parts of a network element that contain ET layer network entities. An ET.MN may be subdivided into a set of ET management subnetworks.ET.MN is referred to in .

Subnetwork consisting of a set of separate embedded communication channels (ECCs) and associated intra-site data communication links which are interconnected to form a data communication network (DCN) within any given ET topology. For ET, the physical channel supporting the ECC is the Ethernet management communication channel (MCC) as defined in . An ET.MSN represents an ET specific local communications network (LCN) portion of a network operator's overall data communication network or TMN.ET.MSN is referred to in .

Element containing entities from one or more ET layer networks. An ET.NE may therefore be a stand-alone physical entity or a subset of a network element. It supports at least network element functions (NEFs) and may also support an operations system function (OSF). It contains managed objects (MOs), a message communication function (MCF) and a management application function (MAF). The functions of an ET.NE may be contained within an NE that also supports other layer networks. These layer network entities are considered to be managed separately from ET entities. As such, they are not part of the ET.MN or ET.MSN.ET.NE is referred to in .
An NNI for the transfer of ETH_CI traffic units over a physical Ethernet interface.Ety-NNI is referred to in .
A UNI for the transfer of ETH_CI traffic units over a physical Ethernet interface.Ety-UNI is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: ENNI is defined by .
In single-ended or dual-ended messaging, the direction and information relating to a one-way measurement from an initiating MEP) to a receiving or responding peer MEP.
Far-end is referred to in .
An initiating MEP initiates measurements by sending request PDUs, and in the case of single-ended messaging, receiving response PDUs.
Initiating MEP is referred to in .

An Ethernet ring node that is common to two or more Ethernet rings or to a sub-ring and an interconnected network. At each interconnection node, there may be one or more Ethernet rings that can be accessed through a single ring port and not more than one Ethernet ring that is accessed by two ring ports. The former set of Ethernet rings is comprised of sub-rings, whereas the latter Ethernet ring is considered a major ring, relative to this interconnection node. If the interconnection node is used to connect a (set of) sub-ring(s) to another network, then there is no Ethernet ring accessed by two ring ports.
Interconnection node is referred to in .

For frames that belong to the same instance of an Ethernet service and priority, in-profile frames are defined as frames for which priority corresponds to a common value <X> and the network has determined that drop-eligibility corresponds to <false>. Procedures to determine drop-eligibility for a frame and procedures to convey priority and drop-eligibility on a frame are network and service specific.
In-profile is referred to in .
OAM actions that are carried out while the data traffic is not interrupted, with an expectation that data traffic remains transparent to OAM actions.
In-service OAM is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: A group representing two or more leaf ports within an RMP EC which can transmit to and receive from other leafs in the leaf group. Leaf ports within a leaf group cannot transmit to or receive from leafs outside the group.Leaf group is referred to in .
An Ethernet connection of which the traffic units are either not encapsulated or encapsulated with a priority tag.Link Ethernet connection is referred to in .
The entity between two of the flow/connection points in a maintenance entity group.Maintenance entity is referred to in .

A group defined, for the purpose of fragment or connection monitoring, between a set of flow or connection points within a fragment/connection. This set of flow or connection points may be located at the boundary of one administrative domain or a protection domain, or at the boundaries of two adjacent administrative domains. The maintenance entity group consists of one or more maintenance entities.MEG is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__title: maintenance entity group end point compound sink function
semantic__clause.semantic__p: A compound transport processing function that accepts the characteristic information of the layer network at its input, extracts and processes the OAM information related to the monitoring of the maintenance entity group, filters the OAM information from within to the maintenance entity group, adapts the information and presents it as the characteristic information of the layer or a client layer at its output, potentially as a (client) layer maintenance signal (e.g., AIS).MEP compound sink function is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__title: maintenance entity group end point compound source function
semantic__clause.semantic__p: A compound transport processing function that accepts the characteristic information of the layer or a client layer network at its input, adapts that information, filters it for OAM information interfering with its own OAM information, adds OAM information to allow the maintenance entity group to be monitored and presents the resulting information at its output.MEP compound source function is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__title: maintenance entity group intermediate point compound function
semantic__clause.semantic__p: A compound transport processing function that accepts the characteristic information of the layer network at its input, reacts to OAM information related to on-demand monitoring of a maintenance entity group and presents the characteristic information without the OAM to which it reacted at its output.MIP compound function is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: An Ethernet ring that is connected on two ports to an interconnection node.
Major ring is referred to in .

A point marking the end of an ETH MEG that is capable of initiating and terminating OAM frames for fault management and performance monitoring. A MEP does not add a new forwarding identifier to the transit ETH flows. A MEP does not terminate the transit ETH flows, though it can observe these flows (e.g., count frames).
MEP is referred to in .
An intermediate point in a MEG that is capable of reacting to some OAM frames. A MIP does not initiate OAM frames. A MIP takes no action on the transit ETH flows.
MIP is referred to in .
In single-ended messaging, the direction and information relating to a one-way measurement from a responding peer MEP to an initiating MEP.
Near-end is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The network element in the transport network that is connected to the customer edge equipment.Network termination is referred to in .
An interface that is used for the interconnection of network elements within a transport network.NNI is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: A measurement (e.g., performance monitoring such as delay measurement, loss measurement) that is running at a specific request. An on-demand measurement has a defined start and end time or date.
On-demand measurement is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: A method to infer a specific status or performance characteristic of a maintenance entity or a set of maintenance entities within a maintenance entity group at a specific time with the purpose of obtaining a snapshot of the performance or to diagnose an identified fault condition or performance degradation.On-demand monitoring is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: OAM actions that are initiated via manual intervention for a limited time to carry out diagnostics. On-demand OAM can result in singular or periodic OAM actions during the diagnostics time interval.
On-demand OAM is referred to in .
A measurement of the performance of frames that is achieved in one direction from an initiating MEP to a peer MEP, or vice versa; i.e., a unidirectional measurement.
One-way is referred to in .
OAM actions that are carried out while the data traffic is interrupted.
Out-of-service OAM is referred to in .
OVC is defined by .
In a given MEP, all of the other MEPs in the same MEG.
Peer MEP is referred to in .

A measurement (e.g., performance monitoring such as delay measurement, loss measurement.) that is running continuously after it has been established. Proactive measurements can only be temporarily disabled.
NOTE: Proactive measurement is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: A method to continuously infer the status and performance of a maintenance entity group with the purpose of detecting disturbances, faults and degradations immediately after their occurrence in order to verify the service level agreement or initiate recovery actions to restore the service to the guaranteed level.Proactive monitoring is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: OAM actions that are carried out continuously to permit proactive reporting of fault or performance results.
Proactive OAM is referred to in .

The R-APS channel connection between two interconnection nodes of a sub-ring in (an)other Ethernet ring(s) or network(s). Its connection characteristics (e.g., path, performance) are influenced by the characteristics of the network (e.g., Ethernet ring) providing connectivity between the interconnection nodes.
R-APS virtual channel is referred to in .
In single-ended messaging, an MEP that receives request PDUs from an initiating MEP and transmits corresponding response PDUs.
Responding MEP is referred to in .
In dual-ended messaging, an MEP that receives request PDUs from an initiating MEP, and does not respond to them.
Receiving MEP is referred to in .
The maintenance entity group (MEG) level providing a communication channel for ring automatic protection switching (R-APS) information.
Ring MEL is referred to in .
The ring link that under normal conditions, i.e., without any failure or request, is blocked (at one or both ends) to traffic channels, to prevent the formation of loops.
Ring protection link is referred to in .

When configured, an Ethernet ring node adjacent to the RPL that is responsible for blocking its end of the RPL under normal conditions (i.e., the ring is established and no requests are present in the ring) in addition to the block by the RPL owner node. However, it is not responsible for activating the reversion behaviour.
RPL neighbour node is referred to in .

An Ethernet ring node adjacent to the RPL that is responsible for blocking its end of the RPL under normal conditions (i.e., the ring is established and no requests are present in the ring). Furthermore, it is responsible for activating reversion behaviour from protected or manual switch/forced switch (MS/FS) conditions.
RPL owner node is referred to in .

A server MEP represents the compound function of the server layer termination function and server/ETH adaptation function, which is used to notify the ETH layer MEPs of conditions of the server layer that may be relevant to these ETH MEPs (e.g., failure or degradation detection by the server layer termination function or server/ETH adaptation function), where the server layer termination function is expected to run OAM mechanisms specific to that server layer.
Server MEP is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: An Ethernet connection of which the traffic units are encapsulated with a service VLAN tag (S-Tag) when they are transported through an Ethernet link. Outside an Ethernet linkThe term "Ethernet link" refers to the ETH link topological component specified in . the traffic units are without service VLAN tag; the information transported in the service VLAN tag is presented as a set of parameters: priority, drop eligible and EC identifier. The link end performs the mapping of those parameters into the service VLAN tag and the demapping of these parameters from the service VLAN tag.Service Ethernet connection is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: Service frame is defined in .

A type of protocol messaging whereby an initiating MEP sends a request PDU to a responding peer MEP, and the peer MEP responds by sending a response PDU that contains the original request data plus any additional data added by the responder. In performance monitoring, the initiating MEP performs measurement calculations.
Single-ended is referred to in .

An Ethernet ring that is connected to (an)other Ethernet ring(s) or network(s) through the use of a pair of interconnection nodes. On their own, the sub-ring links do not form a closed loop. A closed connection of traffic may be formed by the sub-ring links and one or more links, which are controlled by (an)other Ethernet ring(s) or network(s), between interconnection nodes.
Sub-ring is referred to in .
A span (e.g., link/port) connecting adjacent sub-ring nodes that are under the control of the Ethernet ring protection control process (ERP control process) of the sub-ring.
Sub-ring link is referred to in .
A measurement of the performance of frames that is achieved from an initiating MEP to responding peer MEP, and back to the initiating MEP; i.e., a bidirectional or round-trip measurement.
Two-way is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: A transport processing function that accepts the characteristic information of the layer network at its input, classifies the traffic units according to configured rules, meters each traffic unit within its class to determine its eligibility, polices non-conformant traffic units and presents the remaining traffic units at its output as characteristic information of the layer network.Traffic-conditioning function is referred to in .

A transport processing function that accepts the characteristic information of the layer network at its input, classifies the traffic units according to configured rules, meters each traffic unit within its class to determine its eligibility, controls non-conformant traffic units by buffering and scheduling them alternately with conformant traffic units for presentation at its output as characteristic information of the layer network.Traffic-shaping function is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: User network interface is referred to in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: An interface that is used for the interconnection of customer equipment with a network element of the transport network.User-to-network interface is referred to in .

semantic__p.semantic__strike: A timer that is employed by the RPL owner to delay reversion after a forced switch or manual switch has been cleared.
Wait to block timer is referred to in .

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Unified functional architecture of transport networks
Unified functional architecture of transport networks
Unified functional architecture of transport networks
Unified functional architecture of transport networks
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: Recommendation ITU-T G.800 describes a unified functional architecture for transport networks that use connection-oriented circuit switching (CO-CS), connection-oriented packet switching (CO‑PS), and connectionless packet switching (CL-PS) in a technology-independent way.Corrigendum 1 updates clause 3.2.8 to indicate that the description of the forwarding end port should be a type of port, not point.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Generic functional architecture of transport networks
Generic functional architecture of transport networks
Generic functional architecture of transport networks
Generic functional architecture of transport networks
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: Corrigendum 1 to Recommendation ITU-T G.805 corrects some figures that use the symbol for port to indicate points.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Protocol-neutral management information model for the Ethernet transport capable network element
Protocol-neutral management information model for the Ethernet transport capable network element
Protocol-neutral management information model for the Ethernet transport capable network element
Protocol-neutral management information model for the Ethernet transport capable network element
Generic protection switching – Linear trail and subnetwork protection
Generic protection switching – Linear trail and subnetwork protection
Generic protection switching – Linear trail and subnetwork protection
Generic protection switching – Linear trail and subnetwork protection
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: Recommendation ITU-T G.808.1 defines the generic functional models, characteristics and processes associated with various linear protection schemes for circuit-switched connection-oriented layer networks; e.g., optical transport networks (OTN), synchronous digital hierarchy (SDH) networks and packet-switched layer networks, e.g., asynchronous transfer mode (ATM) networks and Ethernet transport networks.It also defines the objectives and applications for these schemes. Protection schemes described in this Recommendation are trail protection and subnetwork connection protection with various monitoring alternatives for individual signals or groups of signals. Furthermore, survivability offered by the link capacity adjustment scheme (LCAS) is described.Generic functional models, characteristics and processes for ring protection and interconnected subnetwork (e.g., ring) protection schemes are defined in other Recommendations.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Functional architecture of connectionless layer networks
Functional architecture of connectionless layer networks
Functional architecture of connectionless layer networks
Functional architecture of connectionless layer networks
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: This Recommendation describes the functional architecture of a connectionless transport network from the viewpoint of its information transfer capability. The functional and structural architecture of these networks is described independently of networking technology. As such, the Recommendation should be taken as the basis for technology-specific descriptions of connectionless transport networks.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Principles for a telecommunications management network
Principles for a telecommunications management network
Principles for a telecommunications management network
Principles for a telecommunications management network
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: This amendment contains additions and changes to the 2000 version of ITU-T Rec. M.3010 as amended by Amendment 1 (2003).

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Considerations for a telecommunications management network
Considerations for a telecommunications management network
Considerations for a telecommunications management network
Considerations for a telecommunications management network
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: The Telecommunications Management Network (TMN) is implemented to support management activities associated with telecommunication networks. This Recommendation introduces essential considerations needed to support installation and operation of a TMN based on the TMN principles, concepts and architecture, which are described in Recommendation M.3010. Issues associated with evolution of new technologies for TMN applications are also identified. BackgroundThis Recommendation is based upon material extracted from Recommendation M.3010 (1996). In this Recommendation the material has been updated, refined, and expanded to assist in the planning, design, implementation and operation of a TMN.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Generic network information model
Generic network information model
Generic network information model
Generic network information model
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: This Recommendation provides a generic network information model. The model describes managed object classes and their properties that are generic and useful to describe information exchanged across all interfaces defined in M.3010 TMN architecture. These generic managed object classes are intended to be applicable across different technologies, architecture and services. The managed object classes in this Recommendation may be specialized to support the management of various telecommunications networks.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Management framework for Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) for CCITT applications
Management framework for Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) for CCITT applications
Management framework for Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) for CCITT applications
Management framework for Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) for CCITT applications
Information technology – Open Systems Interconnection – Systems management overview
Information technology – Open Systems Interconnection – Systems management overview
Information technology – Open Systems Interconnection – Systems management overview
Information technology – Open Systems Interconnection – Systems management overview
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: ThisRecommendation | International Standard, TheSystems Management Overview, is the introductory Recommendation|InternationalStandard to the X.700-Series Recommendations. It provides an overview to thefamily of systems management standards; establishes the basis for partitioningthe systems management standards into separate groups, specifying the scope ofeach group and identifying the principal components within each group; givesguidance on the development of systems management standards and identifies howthey relate to each other; identifies the principles governing conformancerequirements and conformance claims to systems management standards; anddefines terms for use by other systems management standards. Theconcepts defined in this Recommendation | International Standard establish amodel for systems management, identify several aspects of systems management(i.e. information, functional, communications, and organizational), and furtherrefine the model to clarify these aspects.Themodifications incorporated in the 1997 edition include all approved TechnicalCorrigenda to this Recommendation | International Standard and the approvedAmendments 1 and 2 to this Recommendation | International Standard, onManagement Knowledge Management and on Management domains architecture. Thesechanges were required to align the Systems Management Overview with thetechnical contents of approved X.700-Series Recommendations.

semantic__references.semantic__p: The following ITU-T Recommendations and other references contain provisions which, through reference in this text, constitute provisions of this Recommendation. At the time of publication, the editions indicated were valid. All Recommendations and other references are subject to revision; users of this Recommendation are therefore encouraged to investigate the possibility of applying the most recent edition of the Recommendations and other references listed below. A list of the currently valid ITU-T Recommendations is regularly published. The reference to a document within this Recommendation does not give it, as a stand-alone document, the status of a Recommendation.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Terms and definitions for Ethernet frames over transport
Terms and definitions for Ethernet frames over transport

Terms and definitions for Ethernet frames over transport

clause.p: All rights reserved. No part of this publication may be reproduced, by any means whatsoever, without the prior written permission of ITU.

clause.title: FOREWORD
clause.p: The International Telecommunication Union (ITU) is the United Nations specialized agency in the field of telecommunications , information and communication technologies (ICTs). The ITU Telecommunication Standardization Sector (ITU-T) is a permanent organ of ITU. ITU-T is responsible for studying technical, operating and tariff questions and issuing Recommendations on them with a view to standardizing telecommunications on a worldwide basis.

The World Telecommunication Standardization Assembly (WTSA), which meets every four years, establishes the topics for study by the ITU T study groups which, in turn, produce Recommendations on these topics.
The approval of ITU-T Recommendations is covered by the procedure laid down in WTSA Resolution 1.
In some areas of information technology which fall within ITU-T's purview, the necessary standards are prepared on a collaborative basis with ISO and IEC.

abstract.title: Summary
abstract.p: This document is an Implementers' Guide for Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354 (2016-04).
This version contains all updates submitted up to and including those at Study Group 15 meeting in January/February 2020.
This document was approved by ITU-T Study Group 15 on 7 February 2020

sections.p: Implementers Guide ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354 Implementers' Guide
Implementers' guide for Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354

clause.title: 1.Scope
clause.p: This guide provides a list of the definitions that were deleted from Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354 when moved to their source Recommendations.

clause.title: 3.Introduction
clause.p: This implementers' guide is a compilation of reported defects for all versions of Recommendation ITU-T G.8001. In this edition of the guide, reported defects identified as of 2018-10 are given for:
Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354 (2016-04)

The guide must be read in conjunction with Recommendation ITU-T G.8001/Y.1354 (2016-04) to serve as an additional source of information for implementers. The changes, clarifications and corrections defined herein are expected to be included in future versions of the affected Recommendations.

clause.title: 4.Defect resolution procedure
clause.p: Upon discovering technical defects with any components of the texts covered by this implementers' guide, please provide a written description directly to the editors of the affected Recommendation(s) with a copy to the respective Rapporteur (See contacts above). The template for a defect report is located at the end of this guide. Return contact information should also be supplied so a dialogue can be established to resolve the matter and an appropriate reply to the defect report can be conveyed. This defect resolution process is open to any interested party. Formal membership in the ITU is not required to participate in this process.

clause.title: 5.Nomenclature
clause.p: In addition to traditional revision marks, the following marks and symbols are used to indicate to the reader how changes to the text of a Recommendation should be applied:

tr.td: Identifies the start of revision marked text based on extractions from the published Recommendations affected by the correction being described.
Identifies the end of revision marked text based on extractions from the published Recommendations affected by the correction being described.
Indicates that the portion of the Recommendation between the text appearing before and after this symbol has remained unaffected by the correction being described and has been omitted for brevity.
Indicates a set of special editing instructions to be followed.

clause.title: Technical and editorial corrections to Recommendation ITU-T G.8001
[_section_3_2].Section 3.2
clause.p: This Recommendation defines the following terms:

clause.title: [_backbone_ethernet_connection].backbone Ethernet connection
clause.p:
An Ethernet connection of which the traffic units are encapsulated with a backbone VLAN tag (B-Tag) when they are transported through an Ethernet link. Outside an Ethernet link, the traffic units are without a backbone VLAN tag; the information transported in the backbone VLAN tag is presented as a set of parameters: priority, drop eligible and EC identifier. The link end performs the mapping of those parameters into the backbone VLAN tag and the demapping of these parameters from the backbone VLAN tag.NOTE
Backbone Ethernet connection is referred to in [ITU-T G.8012.1].

clause.title: [_backbone_service_ethernet_connection].backbone service Ethernet connection
clause.p:
An Ethernet connection of which the traffic units are encapsulated with the first 48 bits of a backbone service instance tag (I-Tag) when they are transported through an Ethernet link. Outside an Ethernet link, the traffic units are without a backbone service instance tag; the information transported in the backbone service instance tag is presented as a set of parameters: priority, drop eligible and EC identifier. The link end performs the mapping of those parameters into the backbone service instance tag and the demapping of these parameters from the backbone service instance tag.NOTE
Backbone service Ethernet connection is referred to in [ITU-T G.8012.1].

p.strike: The entity that has ownership authority over a set of flow points. The customer may have one or more service instances.
Customer is referred to in [ITU-T G.8011].

clause.title: [_customer_ethernet_connection].customer Ethernet connection
clause.p:
An Ethernet connection (EC) of which the traffic units are encapsulated with a customer VLAN tag (C-Tag) when they are transported through an Ethernet link. Outside an Ethernet link, the traffic units are without a customer VLAN tag; the information transported in the customer VLAN tag is presented as a set of parameters: priority, drop eligible and EC identifier. The link end performs the mapping of those parameters into the customer VLAN tag and the demapping of these parameters from the customer VLAN tag.NOTE
Customer Ethernet connection is referred to in [ITU-T G.8012.1].

p.strike: A type of protocol messaging whereby an initiating MEP sends a request PDU to a receiving peer MEP, which does not send any response. In performance monitoring, the receiving MEP performs measurement calculations.
Dual-ended is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].

clause.title: [_eot_nni].EoT-NNI
clause.p:
An NNI for the transfer of ETH_CI traffic units over a transport layer network.NOTE
EoT-NNI is referred to in [ITU-T G.8012].

p.strike: An entity that is responsible for the protection of a subset of the VLANs that transport traffic over the physical Ethernet ring. Each ERP instance is independent of other ERP instances that may be configured on the physical Ethernet ring.
ERP instance is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].

clause.title: [_ethernet_management_communication_channel_et_mcc].Ethernet management communication channel (ET.MCC)
clause.p:
A function providing a management communication channel between a pair of maintenance entity group (MEG) end points (MEP). The MCC can be used to perform remote management. The specific use of MCC is outside the scope of this Recommendation. An MEP can send a frame with ETH-MCC information to its peer MEP with a remote maintenance request, remote maintenance reply, notification, etc. Configuration information needs to be provisioned to the MEP to support MCC functions. See [ITU-T G.8013] for detailed information and the protocol data unit (PDU) structure of the MCC.NOTE
ET.MCC is defined in [ITU-T G.8051] as EoT MCC.

clause.title: [_eth_ci_group].ETH_CI group
clause.p:
A group of ETH_CI signals that is monitored as a single MEG. For this purpose, ETH OAM is added to one of the ETH_CI signals in the group.NOTE
ETH_CI group is referred to in [ITU-T G.8010].

clause.title: [_eth_ci_traffic_unit].ETH_CI traffic unit
clause.p:
The following set of signals defined in [ITU-T G.8010]: ETH_CI Data (D), ETH_CI priority (P), ETH_CI drop eligibility (DE), ETH_CI server signal fail (SSF) and optionally ETH_CI automatic protection switching (APS). The ETH_CI_D signal carries the traffic unit that consists of the following fields: destination address (DA), source address (SA) and MAC service data unit (M_SDU).NOTE
ETH_CI traffic unit is defined in clause 6.3.1 of [ITU-T G.8010] and referred to in [ITU-T G.8012].

clause.title: [_ethernet_flow_replication_point_ethf_pp].Ethernet flow replication point (ETHF_PP)
clause.p:
Connection point between <Srv>/ETH adaptation source and sink. ETH_CI from source Ethernet flow point (ETH_FP) is replicated and delivered across ETHF_PP to sink Ethernet termination flow point (ETH_TFP).NOTE
ETHF_PP is referred to in [ITU-T G.8021].

clause.title: [_ethernet_replicated_information_eth_pi].Ethernet replicated information (ETH_PI)
clause.p:
Replicated ETH_CI delivered across ETHTF_PP or ETHF_PP.NOTE
ETH_PI is referred to in [ITU-T G.8021].

p.strike: A collection of Ethernet ring nodes forming a closed physical loop whereby each Ethernet ring node is connected to two adjacent Ethernet ring nodes via a duplex communications facility.
Ethernet ring is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].
A network element that implements at least the following functionality.
One Ethernet connection function (ETH_C) with a dedicated Ethernet flow forwarding function (ETH_FF) for forwarding ring automatic protection switching (R-APS) control traffic.
Two ring ports, including ETHDi/ETH adaptation function at the ring maintenance entity group level (MEL).
Ethernet ring protection (ERP) control process controlling the blocking and unblocking of traffic over the ring ports.
Ethernet ring node is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].

An Ethernet service supports an Ethernet flow (as specified in [ITU-T G.8010]). It is determined by the topology of the Ethernet network and a corresponding set of attributes associated with the Ethernet connection (EC), the UNI ports and NNI ports.
Ethernet service is referred to in [ITU-T G.8011].

clause.title: [_ethernet_termination_flow_replication_point_ethtf_pp].Ethernet termination flow replication point (ETHTF_PP)
clause.p:
Connection point between <Srv>/ETH adaptation source and sink. ETH_CI from source Ethernet termination flow point (ETH_TFP) is replicated and delivered across ETHTF_PP to sink filter process.NOTE
ETHTF_PP is referred to in [ITU-T G.8021].

p.strike: EVC is defined in [MEF 10.3].

clause.title: [_eth_path].ETH path
clause.p:
The highest ETH MEG level in a set of eight MEG levels.NOTE
ETH path is referred to in [ITU-T G.8010].

clause.title: [_eth_section].ETH section
clause.p:
The lowest ETH MEG level in a set of eight MEG levels.NOTE
ETH section is referred to in [ITU-T G.8010].

clause.title: [_eth_tandem_connection].ETH tandem connection
clause.p:
An intermediate ETH MEG level in a set of eight MEG levels.NOTE
ETH tandem connection is referred to in [ITU-T G.8010].

clause.title: [_et_management_network_et_mn].ET management network (ET.MN)
clause.p:
A subset of a TMN that is responsible for managing those parts of a network element that contain ET layer network entities. An ET.MN may be subdivided into a set of ET management subnetworks.NOTE
ET.MN is referred to in [ITU-T G.8051].

clause.title: [_et_management_subnetwork_et_msn].ET management subnetwork (ET.MSN)
clause.p:
Subnetwork consisting of a set of separate embedded communication channels (ECCs) and associated intra-site data communication links which are interconnected to form a data communication network (DCN) within any given ET topology. For ET, the physical channel supporting the ECC is the Ethernet management communication channel (MCC) as defined in [ITU-T G.8013]. An ET.MSN represents an ET specific local communications network (LCN) portion of a network operator's overall data communication network or TMN.NOTE
ET.MSN is referred to in [ITU-T G.8051].

clause.title: [_et_network_element_et_ne].ET network element (ET.NE)
clause.p:
Element containing entities from one or more ET layer networks. An ET.NE may therefore be a stand-alone physical entity or a subset of a network element. It supports at least network element functions (NEFs) and may also support an operations system function (OSF). It contains managed objects (MOs), a message communication function (MCF) and a management application function (MAF). The functions of an ET.NE may be contained within an NE that also supports other layer networks. These layer network entities are considered to be managed separately from ET entities. As such, they are not part of the ET.MN or ET.MSN.NOTE
ET.NE is referred to in [ITU-T G.8051].

clause.title: [_ety_nni].Ety-NNI
clause.p:
An NNI for the transfer of ETH_CI traffic units over a physical Ethernet interface.NOTE
Ety-NNI is referred to in [ITU-T G.8012].

clause.title: [_ety_uni].Ety-UNI
clause.p:
A UNI for the transfer of ETH_CI traffic units over a physical Ethernet interface.NOTE
Ety-UNI is referred to in [ITU-T G.8012].

p.strike: ENNI is defined by [MEF 26.1].
In single-ended or dual-ended messaging, the direction and information relating to a one-way measurement from an initiating MEP) to a receiving or responding peer MEP.
Far-end is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].
An initiating MEP initiates measurements by sending request PDUs, and in the case of single-ended messaging, receiving response PDUs.
Initiating MEP is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].

An Ethernet ring node that is common to two or more Ethernet rings or to a sub-ring and an interconnected network. At each interconnection node, there may be one or more Ethernet rings that can be accessed through a single ring port and not more than one Ethernet ring that is accessed by two ring ports. The former set of Ethernet rings is comprised of sub-rings, whereas the latter Ethernet ring is considered a major ring, relative to this interconnection node. If the interconnection node is used to connect a (set of) sub-ring(s) to another network, then there is no Ethernet ring accessed by two ring ports.
Interconnection node is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].

For frames that belong to the same instance of an Ethernet service and priority, in-profile frames are defined as frames for which priority corresponds to a common value <X> and the network has determined that drop-eligibility corresponds to <false>. Procedures to determine drop-eligibility for a frame and procedures to convey priority and drop-eligibility on a frame are network and service specific.
In-profile is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].
OAM actions that are carried out while the data traffic is not interrupted, with an expectation that data traffic remains transparent to OAM actions.
In-service OAM is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].

clause.title: [_leaf_group].leaf group
clause.p:
A group representing two or more leaf ports within an RMP EC which can transmit to and receive from other leafs in the leaf group. Leaf ports within a leaf group cannot transmit to or receive from leafs outside the group.NOTE
Leaf group is referred to in [ITU-T G.8012.1].

clause.title: [_link_ethernet_connection].link Ethernet connection
clause.p:
An Ethernet connection of which the traffic units are either not encapsulated or encapsulated with a priority tag.NOTE
Link Ethernet connection is referred to in [ITU-T G.8012.1].

clause.title: [_maintenance_entity].maintenance entity
clause.p:
The entity between two of the flow/connection points in a maintenance entity group.NOTE
Maintenance entity is referred to in [ITU-T G.8010].

clause.title: [_maintenance_entity_group_meg].maintenance entity group (MEG)
clause.p:
A group defined, for the purpose of fragment or connection monitoring, between a set of flow or connection points within a fragment/connection. This set of flow or connection points may be located at the boundary of one administrative domain or a protection domain, or at the boundaries of two adjacent administrative domains. The maintenance entity group consists of one or more maintenance entities.NOTE
MEG is referred to in [ITU-T G.8010].

clause.title: [_maintenance_entity_group_end_point_compound_sink_function].maintenance entity group end point compound sink function
clause.p:
A compound transport processing function that accepts the characteristic information of the layer network at its input, extracts and processes the OAM information related to the monitoring of the maintenance entity group, filters the OAM information from within to the maintenance entity group, adapts the information and presents it as the characteristic information of the layer or a client layer at its output, potentially as a (client) layer maintenance signal (e.g., AIS).NOTE
MEP compound sink function is referred to in [ITU-T G.8010].

clause.title: [_maintenance_entity_group_end_point_compound_source_function].maintenance entity group end point compound source function
clause.p:
A compound transport processing function that accepts the characteristic information of the layer or a client layer network at its input, adapts that information, filters it for OAM information interfering with its own OAM information, adds OAM information to allow the maintenance entity group to be monitored and presents the resulting information at its output.NOTE
MEP compound source function is referred to in [ITU-T G.8010].

clause.title: [_maintenance_entity_group_intermediate_point_compound_function].maintenance entity group intermediate point compound function
clause.p:
A compound transport processing function that accepts the characteristic information of the layer network at its input, reacts to OAM information related to on-demand monitoring of a maintenance entity group and presents the characteristic information without the OAM to which it reacted at its output.NOTE
MIP compound function is referred to in [ITU-T G.8010].

p.strike: An Ethernet ring that is connected on two ports to an interconnection node.
Major ring is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].

A point marking the end of an ETH MEG that is capable of initiating and terminating OAM frames for fault management and performance monitoring. A MEP does not add a new forwarding identifier to the transit ETH flows. A MEP does not terminate the transit ETH flows, though it can observe these flows (e.g., count frames).
MEP is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].
An intermediate point in a MEG that is capable of reacting to some OAM frames. A MIP does not initiate OAM frames. A MIP takes no action on the transit ETH flows.
MIP is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].
In single-ended messaging, the direction and information relating to a one-way measurement from a responding peer MEP to an initiating MEP.
Near-end is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].

clause.title: [_network_termination].network termination
clause.p:
The network element in the transport network that is connected to the customer edge equipment.NOTE
Network termination is referred to in [ITU-T G.8012].

clause.title: [_network_to_network_interface_nni].network-to-network interface (NNI)
clause.p:
An interface that is used for the interconnection of network elements within a transport network.NOTE
NNI is referred to in [ITU-T G.8012].

p.strike: A measurement (e.g., performance monitoring such as delay measurement, loss measurement) that is running at a specific request. An on-demand measurement has a defined start and end time or date.
On-demand measurement is referred to in [ITU-T G.8052].

clause.title: [_on_demand_monitoring].on-demand monitoring
clause.p:
A method to infer a specific status or performance characteristic of a maintenance entity or a set of maintenance entities within a maintenance entity group at a specific time with the purpose of obtaining a snapshot of the performance or to diagnose an identified fault condition or performance degradation.NOTE
On-demand monitoring is referred to in [ITU-T G.8010].

p.strike: OAM actions that are initiated via manual intervention for a limited time to carry out diagnostics. On-demand OAM can result in singular or periodic OAM actions during the diagnostics time interval.
On-demand OAM is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].
A measurement of the performance of frames that is achieved in one direction from an initiating MEP to a peer MEP, or vice versa; i.e., a unidirectional measurement.
One-way is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].
OAM actions that are carried out while the data traffic is interrupted.
Out-of-service OAM is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].
OVC is defined by [MEF 26.1].
In a given MEP, all of the other MEPs in the same MEG.
Peer MEP is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].

A measurement (e.g., performance monitoring such as delay measurement, loss measurement.) that is running continuously after it has been established. Proactive measurements can only be temporarily disabled.
NOTE: Proactive measurement is referred to in [ITU-T G.8052].

clause.title: [_proactive_monitoring].proactive monitoring
clause.p:
A method to continuously infer the status and performance of a maintenance entity group with the purpose of detecting disturbances, faults and degradations immediately after their occurrence in order to verify the service level agreement or initiate recovery actions to restore the service to the guaranteed level.NOTE
Proactive monitoring is referred to in [ITU-T G.8010].

p.strike: OAM actions that are carried out continuously to permit proactive reporting of fault or performance results.
Proactive OAM is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].

The R-APS channel connection between two interconnection nodes of a sub-ring in (an)other Ethernet ring(s) or network(s). Its connection characteristics (e.g., path, performance) are influenced by the characteristics of the network (e.g., Ethernet ring) providing connectivity between the interconnection nodes.
R-APS virtual channel is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].
In single-ended messaging, an MEP that receives request PDUs from an initiating MEP and transmits corresponding response PDUs.
Responding MEP is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].
In dual-ended messaging, an MEP that receives request PDUs from an initiating MEP, and does not respond to them.
Receiving MEP is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].
The maintenance entity group (MEG) level providing a communication channel for ring automatic protection switching (R-APS) information.
Ring MEL is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].
The ring link that under normal conditions, i.e., without any failure or request, is blocked (at one or both ends) to traffic channels, to prevent the formation of loops.
Ring protection link is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].

When configured, an Ethernet ring node adjacent to the RPL that is responsible for blocking its end of the RPL under normal conditions (i.e., the ring is established and no requests are present in the ring) in addition to the block by the RPL owner node. However, it is not responsible for activating the reversion behaviour.
RPL neighbour node is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].

An Ethernet ring node adjacent to the RPL that is responsible for blocking its end of the RPL under normal conditions (i.e., the ring is established and no requests are present in the ring). Furthermore, it is responsible for activating reversion behaviour from protected or manual switch/forced switch (MS/FS) conditions.
RPL owner node is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].

A server MEP represents the compound function of the server layer termination function and server/ETH adaptation function, which is used to notify the ETH layer MEPs of conditions of the server layer that may be relevant to these ETH MEPs (e.g., failure or degradation detection by the server layer termination function or server/ETH adaptation function), where the server layer termination function is expected to run OAM mechanisms specific to that server layer.
Server MEP is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].

clause.title: [_service_ethernet_connection].service Ethernet connection
clause.p:
An Ethernet connection of which the traffic units are encapsulated with a service VLAN tag (S-Tag) when they are transported through an Ethernet link. Outside an Ethernet link
The term "Ethernet link" refers to the ETH link topological component specified in [ITU-T G.8010]. the traffic units are without service VLAN tag; the information transported in the service VLAN tag is presented as a set of parameters: priority, drop eligible and EC identifier. The link end performs the mapping of those parameters into the service VLAN tag and the demapping of these parameters from the service VLAN tag.NOTE
Service Ethernet connection is referred to in [ITU-T G.8012.1].

p.strike: Service frame is defined in [MEF 10.3].

A type of protocol messaging whereby an initiating MEP sends a request PDU to a responding peer MEP, and the peer MEP responds by sending a response PDU that contains the original request data plus any additional data added by the responder. In performance monitoring, the initiating MEP performs measurement calculations.
Single-ended is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].

An Ethernet ring that is connected to (an)other Ethernet ring(s) or network(s) through the use of a pair of interconnection nodes. On their own, the sub-ring links do not form a closed loop. A closed connection of traffic may be formed by the sub-ring links and one or more links, which are controlled by (an)other Ethernet ring(s) or network(s), between interconnection nodes.
Sub-ring is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].
A span (e.g., link/port) connecting adjacent sub-ring nodes that are under the control of the Ethernet ring protection control process (ERP control process) of the sub-ring.
Sub-ring link is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].
A measurement of the performance of frames that is achieved from an initiating MEP to responding peer MEP, and back to the initiating MEP; i.e., a bidirectional or round-trip measurement.
Two-way is referred to in [ITU-T G.8013].

clause.title: [_traffic_conditioning_function].traffic-conditioning function
clause.p:
A transport processing function that accepts the characteristic information of the layer network at its input, classifies the traffic units according to configured rules, meters each traffic unit within its class to determine its eligibility, polices non-conformant traffic units and presents the remaining traffic units at its output as characteristic information of the layer network.NOTE
Traffic-conditioning function is referred to in [ITU-T G.8010].

clause.title: [_traffic_shaping_function].traffic-shaping function
clause.p:
A transport processing function that accepts the characteristic information of the layer network at its input, classifies the traffic units according to configured rules, meters each traffic unit within its class to determine its eligibility, controls non-conformant traffic units by buffering and scheduling them alternately with conformant traffic units for presentation at its output as characteristic information of the layer network.NOTE
Traffic-shaping function is referred to in [ITU-T G.8021].

p.strike: User network interface is referred to in [MEF 10.3].

clause.title: [_user_to_network_interface_uni].user-to-network interface (UNI)
clause.p:
An interface that is used for the interconnection of customer equipment with a network element of the transport network.NOTE
User-to-network interface is referred to in [ITU-T G.8012].

p.strike: A timer that is employed by the RPL owner to delay reversion after a forced switch or manual switch has been cleared.
Wait to block timer is referred to in [ITU-T G.8032].

references.title: 2.References
references.p: The following ITU-T Recommendations and other references contain provisions which, through reference in this text, constitute provisions of this Recommendation. At the time of publication, the editions indicated were valid. All Recommendations and other references are subject to revision; users of this Recommendation are therefore encouraged to investigate the possibility of applying the most recent edition of the Recommendations and other references listed below. A list of the currently valid ITU-T Recommendations is regularly published. The reference to a document within this Recommendation does not give it, as a stand-alone document, the status of a Recommendation.

bibitem.formattedref: Terms and definitions for Ethernet frames over transport, 8th edition.
